cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Asturias" will leave Suez about Febuary 7
R.M.S "Ortona" will leave Suez about Febuary 21.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Omrah" will leave Port Said January 27
R.M.S. “Oruba" will leave Port Said Febuary 10

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.
For all imformation apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-6

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Staffordshire 6,005 tons, will leave Suez about January 30th.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,636 tons, will leave Port Said about January 26th.
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangood £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.
Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Shortest, calmest, most beautiful sea passage to Europe. Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Sofia, Belgrade, Budapest, Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Chios, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli, Constantinople.

KHARTOUM IN 3 DAYS. Express Steamers leave Suez Docks 5 p.m. every Wedensday for Port Sudan (and Suakin) in connection with Sudan Government Railways Express Luxe service to Kharteum, arriving 8 p.m. Saturdays.

Steamers leave from Suez 5 p.m. every Monday evening for JEDDA, calling one week at Tor, El Wedj, Yambo, Jedda; and the following week at Tor, Yambo, Jedda, Port Sudan, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, ADEN.
For freight or passage apply the Co.'s agencies Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, or for passage only to THOS, COOK & SON, HAMBURG-AMERIKA LINE, REISE-BUREAT or other Tourist Agenecies.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fortnightly from HAMBURG; weekly from ANTWERP ; every 4 weeks from BORDEAUX direct to ALEXANDRIA; homewards every 2 weeks from ALEXANDRIA for ROTTERDAM and HAMBERG. Goods forwarded at through rates from all German Railway Stations on direct Bills of Landing to ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, SYRIA, etc. Special rates facilities for conveyance of cotton, etc. from ALEXANDRIA via ROTTERDAM and HAMBERG to German Manufacturing towns. For tarif and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS. Alexandria Agent.
The Following expected at Alexandria :
S.S. Androos Feb 6 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.

p.name: S.S. Volos now in port discharging bound for the syrian coast on about the 27 inst.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Tuesday, Febuary 4th, to be followed by S.S. Menepthah.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. For particulars apply
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID every fortnight for ALGLERS and LONDON or LIVERPOOL.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. AMARAPOORA 6600 Tons Burthen sails from PORT SAID for Alglers & Liverpool about 31st January
S.S. PEGU 5800 Tons Burthen sailing from PORT SAID for Alglers and Devonport about 10th Febuary
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons Burthen sails from Alexandria for Alglers & Liverpool about 24th Febuary.
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL in 13 days.
The Saloon accommodations is amidships, and the vessels are fitted throughout with Electric Light , and have all the latest improvements.
For further information Apply to the Company's Agents WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: CAPITAL FRANCS 250,000,000 ENTIEREMENT VERSES
Agences d’Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l’étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d’effets sur l’Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,340,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d’Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d’un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d’un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

div.head: Notice to Advertisers.
div.p: The "Egyptian Gazette" has given no advertising agency or company in Egypt any monopoly or exclusive right to act as advertising Agents on its behalf. Advertisements of every description are received at the offices of the "Gazette" from advertisers direct.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: On the bank of the Nile, Formerly the Palace of the late Khedive Ismail. Transformed into a luxurious hotel.
SPLENDID PARK.
Renowned for its afternoon-teas on the West Balcony overlooking the Park. Excellend Tsigane Orchestra, Motor-car running to Shepheard's Hotel and vice-verse.

div.head: HOTEL BRISTOL. CAIRO.
div.p: Full South, Electric Light, opposite Esbekieh Gardens, Large Verandahs, Moderate Charges,
CHAS. BAUER, Proprietor.

The Hotel is beautifully fitted up and is in the most central part of Cairo. Terms for pension fare at the rate of ten shillings a day. Special terms for officers of Army of Occupation. 24,882-31-10-5

div.head: The George Nungovich Hotels
div.p: Grand Hotel, Helouan.- Finest and most luxurious Hotel near Cairo. Patronized by Royalty. Moderate charges. Special terms for residents.

Hotel des Bains.- Most comfortable hotel, opposite the Baths. Pension from P.T. 40. Attached to the above hotels and specially reserved for their clients are the Golf Links (18 holes) with English Professional. Own Golf House in the dessert.
Sulphur Bath Establishment.- Sulphur water stronger than any in Europe. Eight European Masseurs and Masseuses. Every modern improvement.

div.head: "AL HAYAT" Helouan
div.p: First Class Health Resort
Unrivalled Position on the Mokattam Hills
96 metres above the level of the Nile, surrounded by desert.
All rooms full south with sheltered verandahs
Public Sitting Rooms in separate Pavilions communicating by glass corridors.
Electric Light–Steam-Heating–Lift.
Bathing, Air and Diet Cures. Resident Medical Director. All kinds of sports. Own stables. Omnibus meets all Trains.
Ilustrated Prospectus sent free on appplication

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL, Luxor
div.p: NEW FIRST-CLASS HOTEL WITH EVERY MODERN COMFORT
UNRIVALIED SITUATION. MODERATE CHARGES
Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of Army Occupation.
Telegraphic address, "SAVOY LUXOR."

div.head: "San Giovanni," Helouan.
div.p: CAFE-RESTAURANT.
SPLENDID SITUATION ON THE NILE.
Most agreeable fifteen minutes drive from Helouan Station – Service a la Carte – Afternoon Tea – Luncheon and Tea Parties to be ordered in advance. Telephone No. 21

div.head: Borwick's Baking Powder.
div.p: Economical & Reliable.
60 Years' Reputation.
For Home-made Bread, Cakes, Pastry, Scones, Flour Puddings, Meat Pies, &c., &c.
It is Packed in Tins or Bottles, and will keep for years in perfect condition.
Supplied by Store-keepers and Grocers in Cairo and Alexandria.
Manufactory--1, Bunhill Row, London.
Wholesale Agents: Crosse & Blackwell Ltd., London ; C. & E. Morton, London; Walker & Meimarachi, Ltd., Cairo; J. B. Caffari, Alexandria.

div.head: Paris-Lyon-Mediterranean Railway.
div.p: Home from Egypt via the RIVIERA. Travellers returning from Egypt should not fail to spend a few weeks among the chane of the Riviera and acclimatise themselves gradually to the western temperature, before returning to England and other countries where the climate is treacherons. Evory faollilty.
Luxurious travelling. Expro.. cervioo from Marooflies to Paris running in oonnootion
with the Egyptian Boats,

div.head: BIRTH.
div.p: HASELDEN – At Bent Souel on January 29th 1908, wife of Ernest Haskelden, of a daughter

div.head: Cairo Police School
div.p: Thirty three candidates have been atmitted to the Cairo Police School

div.head: Khartoum Show
div.p: The Khartoon Agricultural and Industrial Show will be held on the 21st of February

div.p: The Vitistry of Finance has granted
pletne light in Long Ik

div.head: Company Liquidation
div.p: It has been decided to l ate the Econo munal Residences Limited and Messrs. Paul til, Camel Toneg, and Arout have been appointed liquidators

div.head: Cholea Bulletin
div.p: Pour fresh cases and 10 faths from cho lers are reported from Djeddah The Rabm neh" has concluded disinfection at Tor and wimmenced quarantine

div.head: Cattle Plague
div.p: For the week ending January 2th sixty deaths from cattle plague are reported through Egypt, twenty of these occurred at Asiout, twenty three at Charkieh, nine at Dakhlien at Gharbieh and two at Guerg

div.head: The Brindlal Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe vin Port Said and brin disi will be made up at the GPO Alexandria, at 310 pm on Sunday 2nd for ordinary cor respondence, at noon for money orders and insured articles and stop on Saturday 14 for faroels

div.head: Creville v. Beretti
div.p: The Cairo Mixed Court have given judgment for LE 13,000 and interest has been given tur the Plaintiff in the consolidated actions of # B Greville v. AP de Peretti but opposition having been made thereto, the matter 1 still sub judice

div.head: Collap>se of a House
div.p: Another house has collapsed owing to the heavy rait of the past few days and again the accident has been attenderì with fatal resulta all the occupants, a woman, her son, and three daughters, being killed by the fall The accident Docurred at Belbeis

div.head: Pan-Islamism and Egypt
div.p: The Pan Islamic movement is of vital interest to Egypt and we refer our readers to the leading article in today's inne from the "Times" The letter of "Galata" is too long for reproduction, but is well worthy of perusal by all interested in this remarkable trend of Oriental polition

div.head: New Alhambra Theatre
div.p: This evening the Galenzi tronpe of French comedy, which is performing at the New Alhambra Theatre, will stage vaudeville entirely new to Alexandrians, "La Main Prese by Georges Feydeau On Sunday L. Abbe Constantin" will be given at the afternoon performance Lales are rernested not to wear hata

div.head: YW C.A at CAIRO
div.p: The Sale of Work in connection with an naught House Y W.C.A., Coro, beld at the Semiramis Hotel last December real 225 The expenses, which must necessarily be heavy in this country, amounter tu LE 6 then leaving a balance of LE 165 This w very satisfactory being LE 59 more than last year

div.head: The Ramleh Land Co
div.p: A new Company in the Kamleh Land company, Ltd. It was registered on the nth January. Capital £10,000 in £10 shares Objects To require for investment of reale land, buildings and hereditaments at Ramleh or elsewhere in Egypt, e Noin pois
de Registered office, 73, Salisbury Hone E

div.head: The Sirdar’s Bounty.
div.p: A woman of Abu Selim village in the Damer district gave birth on the 10th January to fit children, two male and two female Three of the children have since died, but the fourth, a
s, is still alive and thriving I'learng of this, the Sirdar ordered that one half of the bounty which is usually given be in to the mother in this case

div.head: The Plague Bulletin
div.p: Fourteen fresh cases, ten death and in cured, form the plague bulletin for the werk en ting January 28th Eight of these cases were reported from Deirout, three from Minich, And one each from Tantah, Makfalout Semalont Sixty two cases have occurred in Egypt this year. Yesterday's bulletin reports one death at Samalut and one case at Deiroute

div.head: The Charity Pantomime.
div.p: Mr G.A. Campbell, of the Coldstream Guards, has finished the book of the panto

mime "Cinderella" and the work is now in active rehearsal. Negotiations have almost been completed with Mr. Galonei and three performances will be given by the "Guards Dra triatic Club" at the Galeni Theatre last week in February, fuller particulars of which will shortly be announced

div.head: Khedivial Decorations
div.p: 'The King has been pleased to give and grant into Tomas Wheeler, Esq. Sub Controller of Accounts, Egyptian Railway Administration, his Majesty's Royal licence and authority to scept and wear the losignia of the Fourth Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Madjidieh, conferred upon him by his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, authorised by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered by him.

div.head: Guide to Egypt.
div.p: The eleventh edition of Mr Halil ke met The Standard Gude Egypt and the Sudan," which formerly hore the name of Cairo and Egypt and Lite in the land of the pharaohs" will prove most valuable band tok to all who visit this country and also to residents. It contains much valuable information in concise form and its descriptive articles are interesting reading An interesting feature of the book is an account of a trip op the Vile by Sir George Newnes, Bart MP entitled from Chitoto Catarit

div.head: Farewell Concert
div.p: A farewell smoking concert was given by the members of the Army Service Corps Sergeants mess karel Nil, last Tuesday evening in honour of members leaving for home with the 8S Soudan Staff Sergeant Major Armstrong presided over a large gathering, representatives of every unit in the Garrison being present, and we supported by Captain Duffus and Captain Crawley Colonel Lodlow sent a letter expressing regret at his inability to be present, Major Myrer, who was unavoidably absent through illness. After the esta! toasts had been given and honoured that of Departing Members Was given in connection with which the'aptain Daffus and Captain Craw ley spoke at length The remainder of the evening WR given op to harmony and an excellent programme pad ways very pleasant evening

div.head: The Tour Eiffel.
div.p: lot might the enrain of the Tour Eiffel rose werd house, which received the Dharvier French operetta troupe tot warmly The BOCANON W the production of a local revue Alexandrie, tout le monde debate by Mr. Provont, when the compere took a very prominent part in the production. The museWAS Arranged by Chevalier Ingenita text of the orchestra, and both his adaptation of well known air and the manner in which be kept honers and chorus in hand were most credible Cher Ingenitu is undoubtedly musician and he deals very cleverly with the TRW material which comes under bis bands The performance last night, it we overlook one or two first night bitebes, was really quite Rool and the piece should have a long run It is bright, lively, and witty, though there are few points which might be expunged with advantage, but we will not deal with these until after the second visit to the performance. The costumes and staging were splendid

His Highness the Khedive received the following persons in audience yesterday mom ing Sir Eldon Gorst who presented Mr Sydney Lowe, Mustapha Maher Bey ex Mudir of Minieb, Count de Bernstorff Count de Vavineux

His Highness Iunched with HR the Duke of Mind at the Semiramis hotel audis entertaining the Duke to dinner at the palace of Koshbeh this evening The Khedive Attended midday prayers to day at the mosque of Abou Ela.
BANK OF EGYPT

It ifying to that despite the financial troubles which have of late been experienced in this country the Bank of Egypt is in a position to make the handsome distribution of 1 per cent for the full twelve months. The otheial statement Just issued states that, subject to the P NR of the e t hy the auditors the directors have decided to recommend the payment of dividend of 10 per cent for the year 1907 of which an interim dividendo 4 percent. We pid on July 12th Instal honor of 204 per here together I per cent for the year, leaving £36.17 After aling 2016 to the reserve to be carried forward to the next ount A W 100 Waddel to Til forward
VITORIA HOUSE.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
Dear Sir. There at
the air to the reorgane the V rs Base, which parently lis t all f all et l
e t that the found tunthir tutan ought to be gone into first all What was object, its constitution
There must certainly le records of its
It was the outer subcripts collect ed frin the British community in 1 7 in honour of our god Queen Victoria's 1st Jubilee and in 19 in bonour of Hier Majesty Diamond Jubilee

Victoris the Good's uemity ought surely to have had some philanthropie intention As at present carried on it appears to me an ordinary boarding house subsidised by the British Colony and free from rent Any young governess or nurse unable to pay a guines a week plus exrs for breakfast and a lamp in ber com, cannot be admitted, by some regula tion, quite we must hope, in variance to the original constitution, which, as far m the older inbabitants can recollect, was intended to sbelter young Englisbwomen out of employ ment
Perhaps the British Consul can throw some light on the matter as there must be papers relating to the foundation of the Victoria House in 1897 pigeonholed safely somewhere
Yours faithfully,
AN EARNEST ENQUIRER Alexandria, 30th January

div.head: WELCOME TO EGYPT.
div.p: "THE GREEN HOWARDS."
A FAMOUS AND HISTORIC REGIMENT.

The Alexandra Princess of Wales's Own Yorkshire Regiment popularly known as the "Green Howards the 1st Battalion of which arrived here yesterday is a very old and distinctive guisbed regiment, and possesses a most interesting history The 1st Battalion came into existence in the closing weeks of 1688 when the Revolution had changed a dynasty. Pore most amagat the partisans of William of Orange was a certain Francis Lattrell, Somersetshire gentleman. To assist the Prince of Orange, be at once set about raising regiment for his service, and so enthusiastically did he work that in a very short space of time he had ten company regiment organised, equipped and armed. This regiment joined the banner of the Prince at Exeter, and Littrell became its first colonel

A nucleus had previously existed in the shape of some independent companies which lasted from the Seven Years' War Its first service seems to have been allocated in the Capacity of mannen A short spell of this service seems to have sufficed for in 1690 we find it in Ireland in William's Army, fighting gallantly at the Boyne and other actions At the death of Luttrell, which abortly followed the Irish campaign, Sir Thomas Erle was appointed to the command, and be brought the regiment to Flanders were it gained laurela at Steenkirk, and Landon and many other actions of the period. Erle rose from a sick beil to lead it at landen, and there was wounded bally whilst cheering on his men. It distinguished itself at the siege of Namur and can home to recruit in 1696 The regiment, which Was subsequently numbered the 19th Regiment of Foot bad a considerable spell of home service after its adventures in Flanders

The regiment served in the Cadiz expedition, and at the capture of the Spanish treasure ships at Vigo in 1702, after which it went to the West Indies, whence it returned, and remained at home until the spring pt 1709, when, at any rate, a part of it joined Marl borough's army in time to share in the famous victory at Malplaquet (11th September, 1709) At the storming of Douay it suffered loss. It was also at Bouchain It was predominantly engaged, likewise, at Pouta Vendin, and in other actions in Marlborough's campaigns After the peace of l'tracht the regiment was many years at home About this time, from

1738 to 1748, it was commanded by Chas Howard, second son of the third Earl of Carlisle, and one of George the Second's "captains. Having green facings, it became known is the "Green Howarda," to distinguish it from the Bafts, which were then known as "Howard's" after their colonel. George Howard, who commanded that regiment for a long period. The regimental connection with Yorkshire probably commenced at this time, although the regiment did not receive its county title until 1782

In 1774, the Regiment went to Flanders and there made a name for itself in many bard fought actions notably at Fontenoy, where the British were basely deserted by their Datch allies Roucoux, Val, etc.against six times their own numbers. It was whilst on this service that fifes were first introduced in the Britsb service and the Green Howards were the first to use that musical instrument At the outbreak of the Seven Years War it raised a second battalion, which was formed into the 66th Foot, and is now the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment late at Alexandria The 19th, the regiment now began to be called, took a prominent part in the famous siege and capture of Belle Isle, outbe coast of Brittany, in 1761; and subsequently was stationed at Gibraltar, whence it returned home in 1771 It went out to Charlestown, Carolina 11 1781, and was present in the wins at Monks Corney, the relief of Port Ninety Six, and the action at Eutaw Springs, and went through much harassing work up to the departure of the troopa and "loyalista" in December, 1782, when it removed to Barbadoen, and ultimately to Jamaica, where it remained until 1791 At the outbreak of the French war the regiment formed part of the expedition which cooperate with the French Royalists at Quiberoni, and afterwards landed at Ostend. It served the campaign of 1794 under the Duke of York, and shared in the disastrous winter retreat through Holland and West
balia to Brunn Its record also shows good work at Vieuport and Guildermalsen. lo 1796 It went out to India, aud soon after we went

Ceylon. A detachment of five companies was sent to Madras in 1799, and took part in the capture of Seringspatam These companies were intended to accompany Baird's expedition np the Red Sea to Egypt, but instead went back to Ceylon. The regiment was employed at Kandy at various times, the massacre of one of its detachments, in 103, Wu of the most tragic character. The regiment was employed for some time in the Travancore district, and sent four companies to Isle Rodriguez, which took part in the capture of Mauritins (Isle of France, in 1810 It was also engaged in the Kandyan War of 1817 18 19, returning home in 1820, after twenty three years continuous service in Ceylon and the Past ludice It served in Demerara and the West Indies from 1826 to 1836, and in Malta, the louian Islands, the West Indies, and North America from 1840 to 1850.

At the outbreak of the Russian War, the 19th was despatched to the seat of war and earned new laurels at the Battle of Alma where it suffered considerably in the attack of the Russian guds, it lorses being two officers,

and 39 non commissioned officers and men -killed and five officers and 174 non commissioned officers and men wounded. At the "Soldier's Battle of Inkerman the handfal of the 19th - for wat and disease bad reduced it to a mere skeleton battalion-had their work cutout for them in stemming the tide of Romian soldiery which for bours threatened to annihilate the slender files opposed to it. Three companies rendered invaluable service in enabling General Codrington to hold the celebrated "Victoria Ridgo throughout the day, and other detachments covered themselves with glory, and lost heavily, nearly half their numbers killed or wounded. It served through out the siege of Sebastopol, taking part in the attack on the Quarties, and the s alt on the Redan. In the latter storm, the forlom bope leadersbip was tossed for between Colonel Unett, commanding the 19th, and Colonel Windham, Assistant Quartermanter General "My choice in modo", said Unett, m he turned over the shilling: "I shall be the first man ini de the Redan". But fortune ordained it other wise be fell badly wounded, early in the af fair Although the attack on the Redan w virtaally failare, throughi no fault of the sol diers, the Rumians were impressed by the valour of the red cats that they ova coated Sebastopol the following morning The 19th PORNOS Bome interesting relics of the Orimean War including the colour belt worn by Lieutenant Stockwell who fell at Alma whilst carrying the colours, and whose life blood left indelible stains upon it, and also

set of Roman droms which still roll proudly at the bead of the battalion on wh oth of September, when the regimental coloar is trooped to commemorate that battle Oure turning from the Crimen in 1856 the regiment had but a brief spell of peace service, being ordered out to India, to take part in the quelling of the Mutiny, remaining in India till 1872, during which period further bonours were won in the Hazarda Expedition and the operations against the warrior tribes of the Black Mountain, gaining the thanks and praise of the Viceroy of India. The second battalion w wided to the regiment in 183 In 1881 the old number was discarded and the regi ment received the designation of the Princess of WalenYorkshire Regiment Three years later, the 1st battalion was engaged in the Nile expedition, and the subsequent Soudan Campaign, under General Sir B Stephenson, being present at the action of Ginnin. Two years were spent on the banks of the Nile, and no battalion could wish for a harder time than fell to their lot in the waste of sand. In 1999 when the Boer War wm looming the 1st Battalion was recalled home from Gibraltar and rapidly mobilised for active service. It embarked for the Cape on the 24th November, numbering 958 of all raoke under the com mand of Lieutenant Colonel H. Bowlen. The mobilisation of the Green Howarda" made them a corpe second to none in appearance, the average heigbt being 5 ft. 9 inches. The battalion on arrival was despatched to the Colesberg district where General Prench w operating against the Boers, and getting their first taste of warfare at Slingerstontein, where D Co. was specially complimented by General Prench for their bravery in turning the Boers off the hills. Atter a month's hard fighting in the Colesberg distriot the battalion joined Robert's force who trapped wily Cronje in the deep ber of the Modder River at l'ardeberg The 19th formed part of the 18th Brigade and mar ched from Enslin on February 11th, and night on up to the 27th, when the Boers surrendered, it was long marching and hard fighting all the time. In the meantime the battalion had distin Roished themselves at the fight for kitchener's Kop, which resulted in the attempted relieving movement by De Wat being defeated

Sergt. now Sergt. May Pickard won the Dia tinguished Conduct Medal for his gallant lead ing of a party to turn some Boers off one of the lower crests of Kitchener Kop After the surrender of Cronje the battalion formed part of the force Lord Roberts led to Bloemfontein, and shared at the operations of Driefontein, Paardeberg cost the Green Howards 162 of all rank, but the battalion went on and won three battle honours. With the victorious British troops it entered Jobannesburg and Pretoria, and in the operatione iu the Fasteru Transvaal w present at the battles of Diamond Hill and Belfast. Long and tedious but valuable the work we afterwards done in garrisoning the blockbouses, and wben peace was proclaimed on June 1st, 1902, all were devoutly thankful During those many, many months of active wartare the battalion lost 226 killed and wound od in action, and 92 dier of disene, heavy toll of brave men who have pain shown bow British soldiers aan die and suffer in their un try'GRUS

The bonouns on the regimental colours of the Green Howards are Malplaquet, "Alma" "Inkerman," "Sevastopol," "Tirah," "Sonth Africa, 1899 1909," "Relief of Kimberley" and "Paardeberg." and they also bear the monogram of her Majesty, her coronet and the date 1875

The battalion bears a very fine reputation for efficieney and discipline and quite recently ber Majesty presented colours to it at Buckin gham Palace. Ita record a shooting battalion is an enviable one.

div.head: CUNARD LINE
div.p: For passengers returning from Egypt in March, particular attention is drawn to the sailing of the "CARONIA," which leaven Alex andria on 7TH MARCH and calls at NAPLE This offers the choice of water trip or an overland journey to LAVERPOOL where pas sage to New York may be secured on the Conard North Atlantieservice which in oludes the largest and fastest steamshipa in the world

div.head: GENERAL AND MRS BULLOCK "AT HOME."
div.p: The ball given on Wednesday night by Major General and Mrs. Bullock wm the first large entertainment given this season at the General's bous, and ww held later than usual owing to the unfortunate illnes of Mrs. Bullock, from which she is now happily recover ed It wus in every way most brilliant and successful fonction and was attended by very nearly five bondred of the best known residents and visitors in the place. The bouse is beautifully arranged for anch entertainments, the drawing room making finely proportioned dancing ball and the ante rooms, and pas Rupes, and staircase affording plenty of sitting out room With such a crowd, dancing was con tinued under certain diffeulties, though & perfect door and excellent music tempted most people. General and Mrs. Bullock received their guests in the ante room and Mine Bullock and Min Ottway were everywhere, doing much to add to the enjoyment of the even ing. The toilettes wom were all delightful, and many of the Indies wore magnificent jewelr. The programme was a long one for Cair, where generally people have to be content with some dozen dancer but the evening power all too quickly nevertheless, in spite of many of the guests having been ap Inte the night before Indeed this dance wu one of the plenantest functions of the season, and General and Me Bullock may rest satisfied in their minds that there was not one guest who did not enjoy him or herselt. The following is complete a list possible of those who accepted their invitations

Major General Ballook is coming to Alex andria today and will stay at the Now Khedivial Hotel

Baron de Kosel Bey left yesterday by the 8.8 "Cairo" for Marseilles. The Baron is proceerling to England in order to make the De ry Arrangements in connection with his dsughters wedding which is to take place shortly in London

Lieutenant and Assistant Comminary, of Ordnance A. Sargeant, AOD, has arrived from Bngland in relief of Lieutenant and H.C.O.T. Rees Mr. Sargeant is very well known in Egypt, this being the third occasion of his connection with the Army Ordnance Department in Egypt.

Mrand Mrs. A 0 Lamplough are leaving for l'pper Egypt by to night's train de luxe They will go straight to Assouan, where they will stay at the Cataract Hotel, and where Mr. Lamplough will exbibit some of bis wonderful water colour drawings,

The Tress which Mrs. Irene Harvey Irene Osgood of Guilsborough Hall, wore at Shep beard's grand annual ball was immensely admired by all present and it has occurred to us that our lady readers might like to have the technical description of name. It wa copied by a firm of Parisian dressmakers from

Plorentine portrait of a mly in Court dress of two centuries ago and was composed of gown of moiré silver cloth, out in the Princess style, with a long train Over this was hang # olinging drapery of fine Rassino white net, most exquisitely band embroidered in frostert silver threal with opal, pearls, and diamonds representing tropical foliage tendrila, vines leaves, fruit and Hwers The only incon venience of this beautiful dress was the great weight of the embroideries jewelr ete, at this added much to the fatigue of the lay's daties With her freue Mrs Harvey wore her world famous fire opals as well as some of her diamond. Her coiffure was very simple one, but not the lens effective on that secount, and she had placed only one small diamond pray in her p ofuse, reddy hair

div.head: PORTS AND LIGHTS SCANDALS
div.p: The Finance Ministry has issued a notice announcing the dismissal of Mr. Bruidas Poggio, engineer in the service of the Porta and Lights Administration, for grave irregularities committed by that official. The dismimal will take effect us from the 26th November last The Financial Ministry has sino inned . similar notice in regard to Mr. Henry Lemaire, an engineer in the same administration. This dismissal is to take effect from the 24th October last.

div.head: MILITARY TAILORD. EGYPTIAN ARMY OUTFITS A SPECIALITY.
div.p: RIDING BREECHES
